<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 377, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 902, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 347, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 267, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Non- calculator  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 568, 88]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 104, 783, 123]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 153, 673, 171]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 201, 685, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 244, 680, 272]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 346, 655, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 560, 400]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 444, 225, 460]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 905, 476]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 482, 770, 524]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 220, 570]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 668, 594]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 630, 220, 645]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 572, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 739, 158, 754]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 737, 555, 788]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 240, 844]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 822, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[330, 72, 667, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 102, 855, 318]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 350, 697, 367]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = |\operatorname {f}(x)|\), where f is a cubic polynomial.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 365, 529, 381]]<|/det|>
Find expressions for the two possible functions \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 380, 482, 396]]<|/det|>
Write each expression in fully factorised form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 380, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 648, 95]]<|/det|>
A circle with centre \(C\) has the equation \(x^{2} + y^{2} - 10x - 4y + 24 = 0\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 108, 146, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 108, 604, 127]]<|/det|>
Show that the line \(y = 2x - 3\) is a tangent to this circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 146, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 790, 327]]<|/det|>
Given that this tangent touches the circle at the point \(P\), find the coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 308, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 448, 144, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 823, 467]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the circle which has its centre at \(P\) and passes through the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 82, 149, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 75, 302, 104]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta d\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 299, 146, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 292, 730, 323]]<|/det|>
Given that \(0 < \alpha < \frac{\pi}{2}\), show that \(\frac{\sec \alpha}{\cot \alpha + \tan \alpha}\) can be written as \(\sin \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 796, 95]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 3x^{3} - 7x^{2} + ax + b\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 604, 126]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{p}'(-1) = 21\) and that \(x - 2\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 146, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 139, 366, 158]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 146, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 718, 437]]<|/det|>
Hence write \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) as a product of linear factors with integer coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 418, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 587, 146, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 587, 754, 606]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\) , solve the equation \(\quad 3\mathrm{e}^{6y} - 7\mathrm{e}^{4y} + a\mathrm{e}^{2y} + b = 0\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 587, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 95]]<|/det|>
When \(\ln y\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\) , a straight line passing through the points \((2,5)\) and \((- 8,25)\) is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 108, 146, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 108, 316, 126]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 148, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 422, 419]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(x\) when \(y = \mathrm{e}^{25}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 401, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 94, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 883, 107]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has a 4th term of \(\frac{8k^6}{27}\) and a 6th term of \(\frac{32k^{10}}{243}\) , where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 114, 584, 133]]<|/det|>
The common ratio of this geometric progression is positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 146, 146, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 145, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
Find the common ratio in terms of \(k\) and the value of the first term of this geometric progression. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 146, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 516, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
Given that this geometric progression has a sum to infinity of 3, find the possible values of \(k\). [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 388, 106]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\quad y = \frac{\ln(3x^2 + 16)}{x + 2}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 327, 136]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 146, 600, 165]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\ln p\) , where \(p\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 146, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 146, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x\) increases from 0 to \(h\) , where \(h\) is small, write down the approximate change in \(y\).  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 645, 94]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 2\ln (3x - 4)\) , for \(x > a\) , and that \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 108, 146, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 420, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the least possible value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 184, 146, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 184, 463, 202]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 920, 202]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 278, 146, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 278, 549, 297]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 278, 920, 297]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 148, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 593, 405]]<|/det|>
It is given that the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) has two roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 770, 437]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), sketch the graphs of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) on the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 297, 466]]<|/det|>
Label each graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 528, 481]]<|/det|>
State the intercepts of each graph with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 481, 455, 497]]<|/det|>
State the equations of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 510, 855, 793]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 83, 678, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 273, 448, 290]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape \(OABCDEF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 289, 292, 305]]<|/det|>
\(AOF\) is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 304, 615, 320]]<|/det|>
\(OAB\) and \(OEF\) are sectors of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 319, 325, 336]]<|/det|>
Angle \(BOA =\) angle \(EOF.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 345, 555, 371]]<|/det|>
\(OCD\) is a sector of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(\frac{4r}{3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 380, 315, 397]]<|/det|>
Angle \(COD\) is \(\theta\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 396, 641, 428]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) lies on the line \(OC\) and the point \(E\) lies on the line \(OD\). The line \(BE\) is parallel to the line \(AOF\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 645, 462]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\) , the area of the shaded region \(BCDE\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 82, 678, 253]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 715, 306]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape from part (a) with region \(OABEF\) shaded. Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\) , the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 288, 918, 306]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 102, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 87, 855, 298]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 314, 668, 335]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(OAB\), where \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 343, 485, 368]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on \(OA\) such that \(\overrightarrow{OP} = \frac{3}{4}\overrightarrow{OA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 371, 484, 399]]<|/det|>
The point \(Q\) lies on \(AB\) such that \(\overrightarrow{AQ} = \frac{1}{3}\overrightarrow{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 408, 804, 446]]<|/det|>
The straight line through \(P\) and \(Q\) meets the straight line through \(O\) and \(B\) at the point \(R\). It is given that \(\overrightarrow{OR} = \lambda \mathbf{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{PR} = \mu \overrightarrow{PQ}\) , where \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 472, 146, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 472, 413, 491]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OR}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) , \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 473, 920, 491]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 426, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 95, 320, 114]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 725, 663, 742]]<|/det|>
Question 12 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 79, 104, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 78, 682, 100]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that its gradient at the point \((x, y)\) is given by \(\left(5x - 2\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 463, 133]]<|/det|>
The curve passes through the point \(\left(2, \frac{32}{5}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 141, 560, 161]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 141, 920, 160]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
